title: Inferring regulatory networks from expression data using tree-based methods

author: Van Anh Huynh-Thu, Systems and Modeling research unit, University of Liège

segmentation: I'm done and I'm from usually in Belgium and I'm here to present the method that we developed for the recovering of gene regulatory networks from expression data.
So the problem we're tackling is this one.
We have a set of genes and we like to discover which are the regulatory interactions that exist between these genes.
So in other words, we'd like to find out which genes regulate the expression of which other jets.
And microarray, I know widely used to measure the expression levels of genes in a cell when the cell is in a certain condition or submitted to a perturbation.
For example, if you overexpress 1 gene, the cell we react to that perturbation by changing the expression levels of gene or subset of its genes.
And the idea is to use the observed expression levels of genes that resulted from that perturbation to recover the regulatory interactions that.
Led to this observed data.
So in order to recover a gene regulatory network, we will use the expression profile of the genes in multiple conditions or multiple experiments.
The G Network that we target is directed graph like this one, where each node represents a gene and an edge directed from 1 gene to another.
One means that the first gene regulates the second one.
Also we consider unsign edges, which means that if there is an edge between two genes, the regulating gene can be either an activator or a representative of the target gene.
And in prayer.

This, like many other inference algorithms or methods, we compute a score for each putative edge of the network with the aims of giving the higher scores to the edges that are the actual regulatory links.
The next step after that would be to set the threshold on these scores and to consider that a gene is in the network if it score is higher than the threshold.
But in our work we only focused on the 1st task of assigning score to each putative edge of the network.
Here is the online of my presentation.
First I will give you the main idea of our procedure or will serve you with a few words about tree based methods.
Of course I will explain our network inference procedure that we call geometry and finally I will show you some results.
The main idea of our procedure is to decompose the problem of recovering a network of pigeons into P. Different sub problem.
Each of the sub problem is a regression problem where the goal is to find the regulators of one of the genes of the network.
Suppose we have our expression data set here where each column corresponds to a gene and each line corresponds to an experiment for each of the piece of problem.

We take one of the genes of the network and we define this gene as the target gene, and the goal is then to determine among all the other genes which are the genes whose expression value is useful for the prediction of the expression of the target gene.

So what we need now is a method which is able to rank for all the P recognition problem, all the putative regulatory genes according to their relevance for the prediction of the target gene expression.
Which leads us to trip.
His methods.
We think that two days and simple methods, like for example, bagging, random forest or extra trees are good candidates for that purpose.

This method are nonparametric, which means that they won't make, for example, they will make any assumption about the distribution of the expression datasets or the one make any assumption about how genes are supposed to be combined to regulate another gene.
These methods can deal with interacting features.

They work well with high dimensional datasets, which is a good point because in most expression data set the number of genes is much higher than the number of experiments, and these methods are scalable.
It is also interesting with this kind of method is that the tree model that is learned from the data can be used to rank all the input features are according to an important score.
This important score measures how well an input feature is useful for the prediction of the output.
How do we compute this important score?
For each node of a tree, we compute the prediction of the variance of the output variable, which is due to the split.
So in our case, the output variable is the expression value of one of the genes of the network.
Then for a single tree we define the importance of a variable as the sum of this variance reduction at each node of the tree, where this via this variable is used as a test.
Finally, for an ensemble of trees we simply average this important scores over all the trees of the and symbol.
OK, now that I have motivated or choice of three bays and simple methods, how do we use them to infer a network?
Llega said in unitary procedure to recover a network of pigeon.

We consider peer aggression problems for each of the regression problem we define a learning sample where the output variable is the expression value of one of the gene of the network while the input variables are the expression values of all the other jeans of the network.
Then we apply a tree, an symbol method on this learning sample and from that remodel that is run we compute for each input gene.
An important score that measure the relevance of an input gene in the prediction of the target gene expression.
So the score which is assigned to an input gene is the score of the edge directed from that input ginsu the target gene in the network.
Once we have all do rankings, we aggregate them to get a global ranking of all the regulatory links.
Most, but we must be careful about this aggregation step here because.

For each of the regression problem as the important score is based on the reduction of the variance of the output, the sum of the important scores of the input in the input genes is equal to the total variance of the target gene, which is explained by the tree.
So in the case of an unpruned tree, which is the case of trees in bagging or random forest.
For example, the son of the scores of the input genes is very close to the variance of the target gene in the learning sample from which the tree is built.
Which means that the higher the variance of the target gene in the learning sample, the higher the important scores of the input genes will be.

So if you if we simply order all the regulatory links according to this important score, we will introduce a positive bias for the edges that go toward the highly variable genes in order to avoid this bias, we first, before applying the tree based method, we first normalize the gene expression profiles so that they all have a unit variance in the learning samples.
By applying this normalization, we make sure that the scores that are infer from the P different remodels Arkham Parable.
Let's see now some results that we obtained with our method.

Every year the Dream Project organizes a reverse engineering challenge, and in the last year challenge there was track coincidental multifactorial network challenge where the goal was to infer 5 synthetic regulatory networks from simulated expression data.
Each of the networks involved 100 genes, and to infer each network we had 100 experiments in each that data set, so the goal was to.
Provide for each data set ranking of all the putative regulatory links.

And as the gold standard networks were known by the organizers, because these networks were completely artificial, they could rank the predictions of each participating team with a score based on the area under the Precision recall curve and the area under the RC curve.
So we took part of this challenge by submitting the prediction we obtained with RG3 method, and we got the best prediction among twelve challengers I indicated here.
The P values that are associated to the area and other curves and these P values showed that the predictions we obtained were significantly better than random guessing.
And after the challenge has ended, the organizers revealed the ghost and our networks, so it allows us to check more precisely the quality of our predictions.
We did is that we computed for each target gene regulated by N regulators.
The rank of these true regulators as predicted by geometry and we did that for different values of the plot.
Here shows the median rank of.

Of these regulators, for an increasing number of regulators, so the rank is presented here as a percentage, so that the first regulator for ranking has a rank of 100% and the last regulator of the the ranking has a rank of 0%.
So the curve here, as you can see, decreases with the number of regulators, which means that given a target gene, the higher the number of its regulator.
So sorry for giving a target gene as the number of of its true regulators becomes higher then the method has more and more difficulties to retrieve these true regulators.
Another feature of the tree that we check its potential ability to predict directed networks.
To obtain the predicted network, so we set the threshold on the interest rate scores predicted by geometry, and we consider that an edge is part of the predicted network.

Is it score is higher than the threshold and we chose the threshold value such that the network contains the same number of edges than the gold standard network, and we did that for each of the five networks of the Dream Challenge.

And then for each of the network, we computed the proportion of edges of the network such that the opposite edge is not present in the network, and we observed that on average the networks predicted by geometry are clearly more symmetric then the gold standard network.
But they still contain a significant number of a symmetric predictions.
But of course, the fact that geometry is able to predict directed networks doesn't mean that the edges that are predicted by the method are the actual regulatory links.
So we also compute.
Did mean error error rate of the method on the direction of the edges?
We consider that the method makes an error on the directionality of an edge.
If this edge is present in the Goldstone on network, it's opposite edge is not present in the ghost, and an network and the method wrongly rank the true edge lower than its opposite one.
Ann, for example, for the predictive networks of dreams such that the recall is 5%.
The mean error rate on the edge directionality is 20%, which is significantly lower than what we would have obtained with random rankings of interactions.
In this case, the error rate would be 50%.
So we think that given an undirected network, Gentry can be a possible plausible approach for directing the edges of this network.
We also compare omitted to other existing inference algorithms, this time only on the real data set.
These methods are three methods based on the computation of mutual information, which are called Clr, acne and Myrna.
It's an one method based on graphical Goshen models.
Do this data set.

We use contains 1500 E. Coli genes an we have the expression profiles of these genes in 900 experiments, and for each method we validate validated predictions with the interactions that are experimentally confirmed in the regular database.
As a first experiment, we adopted the same protocol.

Then in the paper where this data set was used for the first time, which means that we suppose that we know which genes of the networks are transcription factors, and we for each of the regression problem we use as input genes only.
This noun transcription factors.

So with this experiments, here are the precision recall curves that we obtain for each method, and you can see that our method we just give the blue curve here is quite competitive to these other methods, although the precision is a little as good here for small value of recall.
As a second experiment we wanted.
Simulate the same conditions.
Then for the dream challenge.
So instead of using only the non transcription factors as input genes, we use all the genes of the network except the target gene.
But as you can see the results were quite disappointing an for each of the method the predictions were very poor and not better than random guessing.
So now we still have to check why we have so bad results in this case.
In conclusion, except for this last experiment, we obtain quite good results with our method, knowing that this is a nonparametric approach.
This method is scalable and can be easily paralyzed because the P different regression problems are independent of each other and also the different reason and symbol are independent of each other.
And the method is also quite simple and generic and can be applied to other types of data an interactions.
As future work with we like to improve the way we normalize the important score.
For example, without taking into account in the computation of the score, the quadratic error of each tree model by cross validation.
Another thing is that so far all method only assign of schools to each putative edge of the network.

So an obvious step after that would be to develop a method that would automatically set the threshold on this course to obtain a predicted network, and finally the Bayesian networks are also methods that are able to predict directed networks, so it would be interesting to compare ourselves to this family of method.
OK, this is my last slide, so ordinary software is available from this website.

You can find their MATLAB implementation as well as in our implementation and if you are interested we can also check our paper which has been publishing plus one and where the method and the results are fully described.
OK, that's it, and I thank you for listening.
